Original: Per correr miglior acque alza le vele omai la navicella del mio ingegno, che lascia dietro a sé mar sì crudele
Translate: My mind sailed with the ship of ingenuity, directed towards better waters leaving behind the horrible ocean of Hell.

Original: e canterò di quel secondo regno dove l’umano spirito si purga e di salire al ciel diventa degno
Translate: and I will be crowned with that next dominion in which the human soul is cleansed and deemed worthy to ascend to paradise.

Original: Ma qui la morta poesì resurga, o sante Muse, poi che vostro sono
Translate: Be holy Muse, let me rise the poetry, since I am consecrated to you.

Original: e qui Calïopè alquanto surga, seguitando il mio canto con quel suono di cui le Piche misere sentiro lo colpo tal, che disperar perdono
Translate: Calliope raised his voice, accompanying my song with such a loud sound that the ill-favoured gazzes feared that they would no longer be forgiven.

Original: Dolce color d’orïental zaffiro, che s’accoglieva nel sereno aspetto del mezzo, puro infino al primo giro,
Translate: A warm blue glow, which spread into the clear atmosphere to the horizon, like a precious oriental sapphire.

Original: a li occhi miei ricominciò diletto, tosto ch’io usci’ fuor de l’aura morta che m’avea contristati li occhi e ’l petto
Translate: As soon as I came out of the suffocating air, I felt a renewed joy pervading my eyes and heart.

Original: Lo bel pianeto che d’amar conforta faceva tutto rider l’orïente, velando i Pesci ch’erano in sua scorta
Translate: The joyful illumination of the beautiful planet that inspired love dazzled the entire east, clouding the constellation of Pisces that accompanied it with its glow.

Original: I’ mi volsi a man destra, e puosi mente a l’altro polo, e vidi quattro stelle non viste mai fuor ch’a la prima gente
Translate: After turning right, I noticed the dying sky with four lights that no one except our oldest ancestors had ever been able to see.

Original: Goder pareva ’l ciel di lor fiammelle
Translate: The sky seemed rewarded by the reverberation of their colors

Original: oh settentrïonal vedovo sito, poi che privato se’ di mirar quelle
Translate: Or northern hemisphere, sadly you cannot contemplate those stars.

Translate: As soon as I had detached my eyes from them, moving my attention to the north, where the Great Bear had now left the sky.

Original: vidi presso di me un veglio solo, degno di tanta reverenza in vista, che più non dee a padre alcun figliuolo
Translate: I looked beside me at a lonely elder who aroused as much reverence as the affection a son has toward his father.

Original: Lunga la barba e di pel bianco mista portava, a’ suoi capelli simigliante, de’ quai cadeva al petto doppia lista
Translate: He had a long and steep beard, with white and black hairs like his hair. From the temples were tied two braids coming down on the chest.

Original: Li raggi de le quattro luci sante fregiavan sì la sua faccia di lume, ch’i’ ’l vedea come ’l sol fosse davante
Translate: The glow of the four holy stars shone on his face, to the point that he seemed to be in front of the sun.

Original: «Chi siete voi che contro al cieco fiume fuggita avete la pregione etterna?»,
Translate: Where do you come from, for escaping the infinite prison through the underground course of the river?

Original: diss’ el, movendo quelle oneste piume
Translate: With a solemn gesture, he urged us to follow his words

Original: «Chi v’ha guidati, o che vi fu lucerna, uscendo fuor de la profonda notte che sempre nera fa la valle inferna?
Translate: Who enlightened you in the way after coming out of the darkness of the left chasm?

Original: Son le leggi d’abisso così rotte?
Translate: Are the rules of the abyss meaningless?

Original: o è mutato in ciel novo consiglio, che, dannati, venite a le mie grotte?»
Translate: A heavenly decree has been issued according to which you, condemned, will be brought to the rocks that I guard?

Original: Lo duca mio allor mi diè di piglio, e con parole e con mani e con cenni reverenti mi fé le gambe e ’l ciglio
Translate: Then my teacher took me, and with the words, hands, and movements he urged me to kneel down and look down.

Original: Poscia rispuose lui
Translate: He answered him later.

Original: «Da me non venni

Original: donna scese del ciel, per li cui prieghi de la mia compagnia costui sovvenni
Translate: A woman came down from Heaven, and I gave my care to answer her pleas.

Original: Ma da ch’è tuo voler che più si spieghi di nostra condizion com’ ell’ è vera, esser non puote il mio che a te si nieghi
Translate: In view of your desire to be informed in more detail about our situation, there is no reason for my desire to be different from yours.

Original: Questi non vide mai l’ultima sera

Original: ma per la sua follia le fu sì presso, che molto poco tempo a volger era
Translate: It was so close to sin that it would not take long.

Original: Sì com’ io dissi, fui mandato ad esso per lui campare
Translate: As I anticipated, I was sent to help him.

Original: e non lì era altra via che questa per la quale i’ mi son messo
Translate: and there was no other path to follow, except that which we took together.

Original: Mostrata ho lui tutta la gente ria
Translate: I showed him all those who were condemned.

Original: e ora intendo mostrar quelli spirti che purgan sé sotto la tua balìa
Translate: Now I want to see those souls grow spiritually through your guidance.

Original: Com’ io l’ho tratto, saria lungo a dirti
Translate: It would take some time to explain how I brought him here.

Original: de l’alto scende virtù che m’aiuta conducerlo a vederti e a udirti

Original: Or ti piaccia gradir la sua venuta
Translate: Please welcome her when she arrives.

Original: libertà va cercando, ch’è sì cara, come sa chi per lei vita rifiuta
Translate: is sacrificing his life to achieve precious freedom

Translate: You know that you gave your life to gain freedom from Utica, and that one day your body will relive in all its glory.

Original: Non son li editti etterni per noi guasti, ché questi vive e Minòs me non lega
Translate: We do not break the eternal ordinances, for Dante is still alive and I am free from the rule of Minos.

Original: ma son del cerchio ove son li occhi casti di Marzia tua, che ’n vista ancor ti priega, o santo petto, che per tua la tegni
Translate: Marzia, who seems to be begging you to continue to love her through her pure eyes, comes from the circle, oh generous heart.

Original: per lo suo amore adunque a noi ti piega
Translate: by virtue of his love, therefore, bend to us

Original: Lasciane andar per li tuoi sette regni
Translate: Allow us to embark on a journey through the Seven Steps of Purgatory.

Original: grazie riporterò di te a lei, se d’esser mentovato là giù degni»
Translate: I'll be grateful if you agree to be mentioned down there.

Original: «Marzïa piacque tanto a li occhi miei mentre ch’i’ fu’ di là»,
Translate: What I could see during my existence, Marcia was a source of pleasure for my eyes.

Original: diss’ elli allora,
Translate: He then uttered his words.

Original: «che quante grazie volse da me, fei
Translate: that he obtains all that he desires

Original: Or che di là dal mal fiume dimora, più muover non mi può, per quella legge che fatta fu quando me n’usci’ fora
Translate: He can no longer touch my feelings, by virtue of that rule that was established at the time of my departure from the other side of the river hell.

Original: Ma se donna del ciel ti move e regge, come tu di’, non c’è mestier lusinghe
Translate: If a lucky woman guides your steps, there is no need for flattery.

Original: bastisi ben che per lei mi richegge

Translate: Go, wrap this person with a sturdy bunk and cleanse his face from all filth.

Translate: It would not be advisable to present yourself to the prime minister of Paradise with some confusion in his mind.

Original: Questa isoletta intorno ad imo ad imo, là giù colà dove la batte l’onda, porta di giunchi sovra ’l molle limo
Translate: This tiny isthmus, in which the waves break their salty foam and biscuit, is dotted with rushes on the slippery mud.

Original: null’ altra pianta che facesse fronda o indurasse, vi puote aver vita, però ch’a le percosse non seconda
Translate: No plant can grow there with strong fronds or trunk, for it would not be able to resist the forces of the sea.

Original: Poscia non sia di qua vostra reddita
Translate: Then don't come back this way.

Original: lo sol vi mosterrà, che surge omai, prendere il monte a più lieve salita»
Translate: With the sunrise, the sun will give you a clear indication on how to find the easiest route to reach the mountain.

Original: Così sparì

Original: e io sù mi levai sanza parlare, e tutto mi ritrassi al duca mio, e li occhi a lui drizzai
Translate: Without a word, I got up and went to my teacher with my eyes turned toward him.

Original: El cominciò
Translate: He woke up.

Original: «Figliuol, segui i miei passi
Translate: Son, take an example from my teachings.

Original: volgianci in dietro, ché di qua dichina questa pianura a’ suoi termini bassi»
Translate: We return in the opposite direction, as the plain in this area gently descends to the lowest point.

Translate: The rising of the sun had triumphed over the darkness of the night, which fled in his presence and I could admire, from far away the rhythmic motion of the surface of the sea.

Translate: We walked through the desolate plain, like someone finally finding a well-known road after fearing never to reach their destination.

Translate: When we arrived at the area where the dew dueled with the sun, for it was there where there was a presence of shadow and little evaporation.

Original: ambo le mani in su l’erbetta sparte soavemente ’l mio maestro pose

Original: ond’ io, che fui accorto di sua arte, porsi ver’ lui le guance lagrimose

Original: ivi mi fece tutto discoverto quel color che l’inferno mi nascose

Original: Venimmo poi in sul lito diserto, che mai non vide navicar sue acque omo, che di tornar sia poscia esperto
Translate: We reached the deserted beach, never had any navigator managed to go back once landed there.

Original: Quivi mi cinse sì com’ altrui piacque
Translate: As Cato had recommended, Virgil girded me

Original: oh maraviglia
Translate: What amazement!

Original: ché qual elli scelse l’umile pianta, cotal si rinacque subitamente là onde l’avelse
Translate: After having severed the simple map chosen, he saw the latter instantly grow back to its starting point as if it had returned to its original form.

Translate: The sun stood on the horizon, above the highest point of the sundial line above Jerusalem.

Translate: While the night is usually no longer than the day, the opposite position of the sun saw the Ganges rise from Libra in the hours of the evening.

Original: sì che le bianche e le vermiglie guance, là dov’ i’ era, de la bella Aurora per troppa etate divenivan rance
Translate: Aurora's cheeks, a vision of white and red where I was, were painted orange as time passed.

Original: Noi eravam lunghesso mare ancora, come gente che pensa a suo cammino, che va col cuore e col corpo dimora
Translate: We were still on the beach, as someone who considered the way forward, eager but hesitant in acting.

Original: Ed ecco, qual, sorpreso dal mattino, per li grossi vapor Marte rosseggia giù nel ponente sovra ’l suol marino,

Original: allor che ben conobbe il galeotto, gridò
Translate: When he met that sailor, he called me

Original: «Fa, fa che le ginocchia cali

Original: piega le mani
Translate: Take your hands in each other

Original: omai vedrai di sì fatti officiali
Translate: There will be no more ministers like that.

Original: Vedi che sdegna li argomenti umani, sì che remo non vuol, né altro velo che l’ali sue, tra liti sì lontani
Translate: See how he refuses the instruments built by man, not wanting to use oars or other sails that are not his wings, even when he is in such distant places.

Original: Vedi come l’ha dritte verso ’l cielo, trattando l’aere con l’etterne penne, che non si mutan come mortal pelo»
Translate: Look how it hovers in the sky, slitting the air with its feathers that do not vanish like those of human beings.

Original: Poi, come più e più verso noi venne l’uccel divino, più chiaro appariva
Translate: As the divine bird approached us, our vision of it became clearer.

Original: per che l’occhio da presso nol sostenne, ma chinail giuso
Translate: My eyes were not strong enough to bear the direct look, so I was forced to look down.

Original: e quei sen venne a riva con un vasello snelletto e leggero, tanto che l’acqua nulla ne ’nghiottiva
Translate: He came to shore with a small and light boat, so much so that he didn't even touch the water.

Original: Da poppa stava il celestial nocchiero, tal che faria beato pur descripto
Translate: The divine helmsman was at the aft driving station, and he was such that a single description of him would bring happiness.

Original: e più di cento spirti entro sediero
Translate: More than a hundred spirits were sitting in the boat.

Translate: All sang in unison the Psalm concerning Israel's flight from Egypt, including the following verses.

Original: Poi fece il segno lor di santa croce

Original: ond’ ei si gittar tutti in su la piaggia
Translate: Everyone rushed to the beach.

Original: ed el sen gì, come venne, veloce
Translate: He quickly removed how fast his steps had been to arrive.

Original: La turba che rimase lì, selvaggia parea del loco, rimirando intorno come colui che nove cose assaggia
Translate: The group of souls that had been gathered there seemed new to the area, looking around as those who were experiencing something fresh.

Original: Da tutte parti saettava il giorno lo sol, ch’avea con le saette conte di mezzo ’l ciel cacciato Capricorno,
Translate: The sun lit up every part of the day, after kicking out the Capricorn with its infallible arrows from the central position of the heavenly universe.

Original: quando la nova gente alzò la fronte ver’ noi, dicendo a noi
Translate: When the newcomers asked us for help, telling us

Translate: Show us how to reach the mountain if you know the route.

Original: E Virgilio rispuose
Translate: Virgil gave him an answer.

Original: «Voi credete forse che siamo esperti d’esto loco
Translate: It may be that you think we are experts in this area.

Original: ma noi siam peregrin come voi siete
Translate: We're strangers the same way you are.

Original: Dianzi venimmo, innanzi a voi un poco, per altra via, che fu sì aspra e forte, che lo salire omai ne parrà gioco»
Translate: We arrived immediately before you on a path so difficult to make the ascension of the mountain a breeze.

Original: L’anime, che si fuor di me accorte, per lo spirare, ch’i’ era ancor vivo, maravigliando diventaro smorte
Translate: The souls, discovering that I was still alive watching me breathe, grew free from wonder.

Original: E come a messagger che porta ulivo tragge la gente per udir novelle, e di calcar nessun si mostra schivo,
Translate: The crowd gathers around the messenger who brings news of peace, and everyone gladly comes.

Original: così al viso mio s’affisar quelle anime fortunate tutte quante, quasi oblïando d’ire a farsi belle
Translate: The lucky souls, as if they had forgotten the need for purification, gathered around my face.

Original: Io vidi una di lor trarresi avante per abbracciarmi con sì grande affetto, che mosse me a far lo somigliante
Translate: When one of them came forward to embrace me with such warmth, I felt the need to return the gesture.

Original: Ohi ombre vane, fuor che ne l’aspetto

Translate: The shadow smiled, then went away, and I went behind it a little further.

Original: Soavemente disse ch’io posasse
Translate: He kindly ordered me to stop

Original: allor conobbi chi era, e pregai che, per parlarmi, un poco s’arrestasse
Translate: Then I recognized him and asked him to linger with me for a while.

Original: Rispuosemi
Translate: He answered me.

Original: «Così com’ io t’amai nel mortal corpo, così t’amo sciolta
Translate: "My love, as I have loved your physical essence, I likewise have a deep affection for you in my spiritual form.

Original: però m’arresto
Translate: That's why I'm interrupting.

Original: ma tu perché vai?»
Translate: Why are you here?

Original: «Casella mio, per tornar altra volta là dov’ io son, fo io questo vïaggio», diss’ io
Translate: "I'm heading for this trip back to my original destination."

Original: «ma a te com’ è tanta ora tolta?»
Translate: Why did you come so late?

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: I to him

Original: «Nessun m’è fatto oltraggio, se quei che leva quando e cui li piace, più volte m’ha negato esto passaggio
Translate: "No affront has been inflicted upon me, although the angel, who does what he wants arbitrarily, has hindered me several times in reaching this place.

Original: ché di giusto voler lo suo si face
Translate: His desire corresponds to what has been established by God.

Original: veramente da tre mesi elli ha tolto chi ha voluto intrar, con tutta pace
Translate: For three months, he's allowed it to anyone who wants to get on the boat, without opposing it.

Original: Ond’ io, ch’era ora a la marina vòlto dove l’acqua di Tevero s’insala, benignamente fu’ da lui ricolto
Translate: Then I, looking toward the ocean where the Tiber is thrown, was kindly received by him.

Original: A quella foce ha elli or dritta l’ala, però che sempre quivi si ricoglie qual verso Acheronte non si cala»
Translate: He rose with the wing in the direction of the mouth, for every soul that is not destined for damnation always tends to reach that place.

Original: E io

Translate: If a law does not have the ability to eliminate my remembrance or love to sing, which usually appeased all my needs.

Original: di ciò ti piaccia consolare alquanto l’anima mia, che, con la sua persona venendo qui, è affannata tanto»
Translate: Please ease my suffering a little, for the soul is tired of the long journey with the physical body.

Original: ‘Amor che ne la mente mi ragiona’ cominciò elli allor sì dolcemente, che la dolcezza ancor dentro mi suona
Translate: Then he began to sing "Love that in my mind reasons" so softly, so as to leave an echo of that melody still within me.

Original: Lo mio maestro e io e quella gente ch’eran con lui parevan sì contenti, come a nessun toccasse altro la mente
Translate: My teacher and I, along with the souls who were with him, seemed so happy, as if no thought had disturbed our minds.

Original: Noi eravam tutti fissi e attenti a le sue note
Translate: All of us were listening carefully to the music.

Original: ed ecco il veglio onesto gridando
Translate: Here came the majestic elder who was screaming

Original: «Che è ciò, spiriti lenti?
Translate: What are you trying to say, slow spirits?

Original: qual negligenza, quale stare è questo?
Translate: How can this negligence and inertia be described?

Original: Correte al monte a spogliarvi lo scoglio ch’esser non lascia a voi Dio manifesto»
Translate: Race to the mountain to become transparent that will not prevent you from seeing God.

Original: Come quando, cogliendo biado o loglio, li colombi adunati a la pastura, queti, sanza mostrar l’usato orgoglio,
Translate: Quietly, as if the action were a routine, the doves gathered to eat both biada and loaf without flaunting any boasting.

Original: se cosa appare ond’ elli abbian paura, subitamente lasciano star l’esca, perch’ assaliti son da maggior cura
Translate: If something alarms them, they no longer pay attention to food because fear has become dominant.

Original: così vid’ io quella masnada fresca lasciar lo canto, e fuggir ver’ la costa, com’ om che va, né sa dove rïesca
Translate: As I watched, I saw those newly arrived souls moving away from their songs, and heading towards the mountain as if they did not have a specific destination.

Original: né la nostra partita fu men tosta
Translate: and our escape was just as hasty

Original: Avvegna che la subitana fuga dispergesse color per la campagna,
Translate: Despite the desperate escape forced souls to move away quickly on the beach,

Original: rivolti al monte ove ragion ne fruga, i’ mi ristrinsi a la fida compagna
Translate: toward the summit where divine judgment worries us, I clinged to my reliable guidance.

Original: e come sare’ io sanza lui corso? chi m’avria tratto su per la montagna? El mi parea da sé stesso rimorso
Translate: He feels remorse, but how could I have climbed up the mountain without him?

Original: o dignitosa coscïenza e netta, come t’è picciol fallo amaro morso
Translate: Oh, respectable and immaculate conscience, with which bitterness punishes you even the smallest mistake.

Original: Quando li piedi suoi lasciar la fretta, che l’onestade ad ogn’ atto dismaga,
Translate: When his steps turned away from the frenzy that reduces elegance to every action,

Original: la mente mia, che prima era ristretta,
Translate: My mind, which previously focused on a single concept, is now free to wander.

Original: lo ’ntento rallargò, sì come vaga, e diedi ’l viso mio incontr’ al poggio che ’nverso ’l ciel più alto si dislaga
Translate: It opened like a veil, and I turned towards the mountain that stood higher than any other towards the sky.

Original: Lo sol, che dietro fiammeggiava roggio, rotto m’era dinanzi a la figura, ch’avëa in me de’ suoi raggi l’appoggio
Translate: My body, standing between me and the bright red-orange sun behind my back, blocked the rays before reaching me.

Original: Io mi volsi dallato con paura d’essere abbandonato, quand’ io vidi solo dinanzi a me la terra oscura
Translate: With fear of being abandoned, I turned on my side, observing the solitary shadow before me.

Original: e ’l mio conforto
Translate: My consolation

Original: «Perché pur diffidi?», a dir mi cominciò tutto rivolto
Translate: "Why don't you trust me?" he asked me very carefully.

Original: «non credi tu me teco e ch’io ti guidi? Vespero è già colà dov’ è sepolto lo corpo dentro al quale io facea ombra
Translate: It's already evening where the remains of that body rest, whose shadows I projected; don't you think I'm here for you, as a guide?

Original: Napoli l’ha, e da Brandizio è tolto
Translate: It comes from Brindisi and is located in Naples.

Translate: If my shoulders do not create a shadow in front of me, then there will be nothing left to prevent the sun from reaching every corner of the sky.

Original: A sofferir tormenti, caldi e geli simili corpi la Virtù dispone che, come fa, non vuol ch’a noi si sveli
Translate: In obedience to the divine will, bodily beings are subjected to tormenting hot and cold and we are unable to understand how it can be made possible.

Original: Matto è chi spera che nostra ragione possa trascorrer la infinita via che tiene una sustanza in tre persone
Translate: Those who believe that our logic is able to cross the endless road that unites a single essence divided into three people are considered crazy.

Original: State contenti, umana gente, al quia
Translate: Accept, men, this

Translate: If you had been able to observe everything, Mary would not have been forced to give birth to Jesus.

Original: e disïar vedeste sanza frutto tai che sarebbe lor disio quetato, ch’etternalmente è dato lor per lutto
Translate: Philosophers so deep that they seem able to satisfy their desire if possible, but that in the end they have seen their ideals fail despite diligently trying to achieve them, represent their eternal punishment.

Original: io dico d’Aristotile e di Plato e di molt’ altri»
Translate: I'm referring to Aristotle, Plato and several other characters.

Original: e qui chinò la fronte, e più non disse, e rimase turbato
Translate: At that point, he lowered his head in silence, troubled; adding nothing else.

Original: Noi divenimmo intanto a piè del monte

Original: quivi trovammo la roccia sì erta, che ’ndarno vi sarien le gambe pronte
Translate: the rocky wall was so steep that we could only dream of climbing it with our legs

Original: Tra Lerice e Turbìa la più diserta, la più rotta ruina è una scala, verso di quella, agevole e aperta
Translate: Compared to that, the steepest and most rugged rock in Liguria is a piece of cake.

Original: «Or chi sa da qual man la costa cala»,
Translate: I wonder which part of the wall is less inclined now.

Original: disse ’l maestro mio fermando ’l passo,
Translate: My master interrupted his step and spoke

Original: «sì che possa salir chi va sanz’ ala?»
Translate: How can anyone with no wings ascend?

Original: E mentre ch’e’ tenendo ’l viso basso essaminava del cammin la mente, e io mirava suso intorno al sasso,
Translate: As he paused to reflect with low gaze, on which road to take, I looked at the surrounding landscape, above the rock.

Original: da man sinistra m’apparì una gente d’anime, che movieno i piè ver’ noi, e non pareva, sì venïan lente
Translate: From one direction to the left, I spotted a group of people who approached us gently and slowly.

Original: «Leva», diss’ io, «maestro, li occhi tuoi
Translate: I cried out "Master, stand up and look."

Original: ecco di qua chi ne darà consiglio, se tu da te medesmo aver nol puoi»
Translate: Who's gonna lead you if you can't find the answers on your own?

Original: Guardò allora, e con libero piglio rispuose
Translate: He then turned around, with a serene expression, and answered.

Original: «Andiamo in là, ch’ei vegnon piano
Translate: We try to get away because they are moving slowly towards us.

Original: e tu ferma la spene, dolce figlio»
Translate: heart up your hope, kind son

Translate: After taking a thousand steps, he was still so far away from us that a good pitcher couldn't get there with a rock hurled from his hand.

Original: quando si strinser tutti ai duri massi de l’alta ripa, e stetter fermi e stretti com’ a guardar, chi va dubbiando, stassi
Translate: They rushed against the rock of the mountain, in a kind of fear - inspiring expectation as if they were undecided about what to do.

Original: «O ben finiti, o già spiriti eletti», Virgilio incominciò,
Translate: Virgil began the divine spirits selected by God's grace for salvation.

Original: «per quella pace ch’i’ credo che per voi tutti s’aspetti, ditene dove la montagna giace, sì che possibil sia l’andare in suso
Translate: Show us the sweetest path in this quest for peace, so that we can embark on the ascent.

Original: ché perder tempo a chi più sa più spiace»
Translate: The more you know, the more you feel guilty about not moving on.

Original: Come le pecorelle escon del chiuso a una, a due, a tre, e l’altre stanno timidette atterrando l’occhio e ’l muso

Original: e ciò che fa la prima, e l’altre fanno, addossandosi a lei, s’ella s’arresta, semplici e quete, e lo ’mperché non sanno
Translate: If the former were to rest, quiet and passive, the others would cling to her without even knowing why.

Original: sì vid’ io muovere a venir la testa di quella mandra fortunata allotta, pudica in faccia e ne l’andare onesta
Translate: With my eyes I saw the leader of that lucky group of people approaching our position, who looked modest and was moved by great dignity.

Original: Come color dinanzi vider rotta la luce in terra dal mio destro canto, sì che l’ombra era da me a la grotta,
Translate: When they saw that my profile was projected onto the rocky wall on the right,

Original: restaro, e trasser sé in dietro alquanto, e tutti li altri che venieno appresso, non sappiendo ’l perché, fenno altrettanto

Original: «Sanza vostra domanda io vi confesso che questo è corpo uman che voi vedete
Translate: I assure you without asking you that this body is made of flesh and bones.

Original: per che ’l lume del sole in terra è fesso
Translate: The shadow of the sun prevents the arrival of luminosity

Original: Così ’l maestro

Original: e quella gente degna «Tornate», disse, «intrate innanzi dunque», coi dossi de le man faccendo insegna
Translate: And those worthy souls exhorted "Return back," accompanying their counsel with a nod of hands.

Original: E un di loro incominciò
Translate: One of them began.

Original: «Chiunque tu se’, così andando, volgi ’l viso

Original: pon mente se di là mi vedesti unque»

Original: Io mi volsi ver’ lui e guardail fiso

Original: biondo era e bello e di gentile aspetto, ma l’un de’ cigli un colpo avea diviso
Translate: He had the beauty of the nobles, blond hair and two regular eyebrows, apart from one that had been divided by an impressive wound inflicted by a sword.

Original: Quand’ io mi fui umilmente disdetto d’averlo visto mai, el disse
Translate: When I humbledly told him that I had never met him, he replied:

Original: «Or vedi»

Original: e mostrommi una piaga a sommo ’l petto

Original: Poi sorridendo disse
Translate: He giggled and uttered

Translate: I am Manfredi, great-grandson of Empress Constance.

Original: e dichi ’l vero a lei, s’altro si dice

Original: Poscia ch’io ebbi rotta la persona di due punte mortali, io mi rendei, piangendo, a quei che volontier perdona
Translate: After suffering two deadly wounds, I turned to the One who gladly forgave me in repentance and tears.

Original: Orribil furon li peccati miei

Original: ma la bontà infinita ha sì gran braccia, che prende ciò che si rivolge a lei

Original: Se ’l pastor di Cosenza, che a la caccia di me fu messo per Clemente allora, avesse in Dio ben letta questa faccia,
Translate: If the bishop of Cosenza, who at that time was urged by Pope Clement IV to take action against me, had known this face of divine mercy,

Original: l’ossa del corpo mio sarieno ancora in co del ponte presso a Benevento, sotto la guardia de la grave mora
Translate: My bones would still be buried in the rocks at the head of the bridge at Benevento.

Original: Or le bagna la pioggia e move il vento di fuor dal regno, quasi lungo ’l Verde, dov’ e’ le trasmutò a lume spento
Translate: The rain wet the ashes and the wind scattered them around Naples, almost near the river Liri, where it had been transferred in the dark.

Original: Per lor maladizion sì non si perde, che non possa tornar, l’etterno amore, mentre che la speranza ha fior del verde
Translate: Despite the curse of the Church, eternal divine love is not exhausted to the point of not being able to return, provided that there is still some hope.

Original: Vero è che quale in contumacia more di Santa Chiesa, ancor ch’al fin si penta, star li convien da questa ripa in fore,
Translate: Whoever dies without recognizing the authority of the Holy Church, even if he repents before he breathes, will not be acquitted.

Original: per ognun tempo ch’elli è stato, trenta, in sua presunzïon, se tal decreto più corto per buon prieghi non diventa
Translate: If good prayers succeed in shortening the decree, it must stay in Antipurgatory for a period thirty times greater than that spent in its rebellion.

Original: Vedi oggimai se tu mi puoi far lieto, revelando a la mia buona Costanza come m’hai visto, e anco esto divieto
Translate: Examine if you can make Constance happy, showing her how you saw me and also this prohibition.

Original: ché qui per quei di là molto s’avanza»
Translate: In this place, the prayer of the living results in interesting benefits.

Original: Quando per dilettanze o ver per doglie, che alcuna virtù nostra comprenda, l’anima bene ad essa si raccoglie, par ch’a nulla potenza più intenda
Translate: Once the soul focuses on a feeling, such as joy or sorrow, and arouses some good character trait in us,

Original: e questo è contra quello error che crede ch’un’anima sovr’ altra in noi s’accenda
Translate: Whoever believes that there is only one soul in us is wrong.

Original: E però, quando s’ode cosa o vede che tegna forte a sé l’anima volta, vassene ’l tempo e l’uom non se n’avvede
Translate: When one is fascinated by something that has the ability to capture all the attention and to kidnap the soul, time seems to fly without any perception on the part of man.

Original: ch’altra potenza è quella che l’ascolta, e altra è quella c’ha l’anima intera
Translate: The strength that you feel in the flow of time is one, while that possessed by the whole spirit is completely different.

Original: questa è quasi legata e quella è sciolta
Translate: The first one is loose, while the second one is almost clinging.

Original: Di ciò ebb’ io esperïenza vera, udendo quello spirto e ammirando
Translate: I got a direct confirmation from this, listening to that spirit that was amazed.

Original: ché ben cinquanta gradi salito era lo sole, e io non m’era accorto, quando venimmo ove quell’ anime ad una gridaro a noi
Translate: The sun was so bright that by now it had reached a height of fifty degrees, but I did not realize it until those souls ordered us to stop.

Original: «Qui è vostro dimando»

Original: Maggiore aperta molte volte impruna con una forcatella di sue spine l’uom de la villa quando l’uva imbruna,
Translate: The farmer, once the grapes have reached the ripening, seals with some thorns a gap.

Original: che non era la calla onde salìne lo duca mio, e io appresso, soli, come da noi la schiera si partìne
Translate: The path that my teacher and I went up alone spread as soon as the crowd of souls left.

Original: Vassi in Sanleo e discendesi in Noli, montasi su in Bismantova e ’n Cacume con esso i piè
Translate: You go to Sanleo and you come from Noli; you mount the Bismantova and Mount Cacume only with your own legs.

Original: ma qui convien ch’om voli

Original: dico con l’ale snelle e con le piume del gran disio, di retro a quel condotto che speranza mi dava e facea lume
Translate: Flying with gracefulness, puffed up with hope and great desire the feathers of the soul following the comfort offered by the guide that opened the way.

Original: Noi salavam per entro ’l sasso rotto, e d’ogne lato ne stringea lo stremo, e piedi e man volea il suol di sotto

Original: Poi che noi fummo in su l’orlo suppremo de l’alta ripa, a la scoperta piaggia,
Translate: Arriving at the upper limit of the steep wall, where the slope was sweeter,

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: I to him

Original: «Nessun tuo passo caggia
Translate: "No step of you should be directed downwards.

Original: pur su al monte dietro a me acquista, fin che n’appaia alcuna scorta saggia»
Translate: Keep going up without me until we meet someone who can drive us.

Original: Lo sommo er’ alto che vincea la vista, e la costa superba più assai che da mezzo quadrante a centro lista
Translate: The summit was so high that you couldn't see, and the steepest descent of the line on the middle of the quadrant.

Original: Io era lasso, quando cominciai
Translate: Hi, I was running out of energy when I said hello.

Original: «O dolce padre, volgiti, e rimira com’ io rimango sol, se non restai»
Translate: Loved Father, turn your head and see how they are only if you don't stop.

Original: «Figliuol mio», disse, «infin quivi ti tira», additandomi un balzo poco in sùe che da quel lato il poggio tutto gira
Translate: He showed me a shelf placed higher, surrounding the mountain, and said "My son, do your best to reach it."

Original: Sì mi spronaron le parole sue, ch’i’ mi sforzai carpando appresso lui, tanto che ’l cinghio sotto i piè mi fue
Translate: His words pushed me to such an extent that I marched behind him until I reached the shelf.

Original: A seder ci ponemmo ivi ambedui vòlti a levante ond’ eravam saliti, che suole a riguardar giovare altrui
Translate: We both sat there, facing eastwards in the direction from which we had ascended, which was pleasant to admire.

Original: Li occhi prima drizzai ai bassi liti

Original: poscia li alzai al sole, e ammirava che da sinistra n’eravam feriti
Translate: I looked up at the sun and was amazed that that glow came from the left

Original: Ben s’avvide il poeta ch’ïo stava stupido tutto al carro de la luce, ove tra noi e Aquilone intrava
Translate: Virgil noticed that I was amazed to see the chariot of light at that moment when he approached us and the north.

Original: Ond’ elli a me

Original: «Se Castore e Poluce fossero in compagnia di quello specchio che sù e giù del suo lume conduce,
Translate: If the Gemini constellation were coordinated with that reflection that raises and lowers light,

Original: tu vedresti il Zodïaco rubecchio ancora a l’Orse più stretto rotare, se non uscisse fuor del cammin vecchio
Translate: You would see the Zodiac blush further as he moves north, unless he abandons the usual path.

Original: Come ciò sia, se ’l vuoi poter pensare, dentro raccolto, imagina Sïòn con questo monte in su la terra stare sì,
Translate: To understand how this is feasible, it accurately displays Jerusalem and Purgatory on Earth.

Original: ch’amendue hanno un solo orizzòn e diversi emisperi
Translate: in such a way that they unite their visions in one direction but also maintain their individuality.

Original: onde la strada che mal non seppe carreggiar Fetòn, vedrai come a costui convien che vada da l’un,
Translate: You will see that the trajectory of the sun must travel a different direction if seen from Jerusalem.

Original: quando a colui da l’altro fianco, se lo ’ntelletto tuo ben chiaro bada»
Translate: And, if your mind is aligned, for those who are present here I said,

Original: «Certo, maestro mio,» diss’ io, «unquanco non vid’ io chiaro sì com’ io discerno là dove mio ingegno parea manco,
Translate: "Never as now, compared to before, do I fully understand the things that I could not understand" I told my teacher.

Original: che ’l mezzo cerchio del moto superno, che si chiama Equatore in alcun’ arte,
Translate: The Primo Mobile is represented as a circle in astronomical art, known as the equator.

Original: e che sempre riman tra ’l sole e ’l verno, per la ragion che di’, quinci si parte verso settentrïon, quanto li Ebrei vedevan lui verso la calda parte
Translate: And it always remains equidistant between summer and winter, just as the Jews saw the distance that separated them from the north.

Original: Ma se a te piace, volontier saprei quanto avemo ad andar
Translate: If you agree, I'd like to know how far we have to go?

Original: ché ’l poggio sale più che salir non posson li occhi miei»
Translate: Where my gaze comes, the mountain is even higher.

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Questa montagna è tale, che sempre al cominciar di sotto è grave
Translate: Facing the ascent of this mountain is always very tiring from the beginning.

Original: e quant’ om più va sù, e men fa male
Translate: As you get up, the difficulty decreases

Original: Però, quand’ ella ti parrà soave tanto, che sù andar ti fia leggero com’ a seconda giù andar per nave,
Translate: When it seems so pleasant to you that going up will be like driving the stream of a river,

Original: allor sarai al fin d’esto sentiero
Translate: At the end of this path

Original: quivi di riposar l’affanno aspetta

Original: Più non rispondo, e questo so per vero»
Translate: I don't have to add any more, and I know that's the truth.

Original: E com’ elli ebbe sua parola detta, una voce di presso sonò
Translate: As soon as Virgil had finished his prayer, he heard a voice behind his back.

Original: «Forse che di sedere in pria avrai distretta»
Translate: You may need to sit down early.

Original: Al suon di lei ciascun di noi si torse, e vedemmo a mancina un gran petrone, del qual né io né ei prima s’accorse
Translate: We both turned around hearing the voice, and then noticed a massive rock on our left that none of us had seen before.

Original: Là ci traemmo
Translate: We went there.

Original: e ivi eran persone che si stavano a l’ombra dietro al sasso come l’uom per negghienza a star si pone
Translate: We found souls who had watered in the shadows behind the rock, as if they were in a state of unselfish rest.

Translate: One of them, he seemed exhausted, was sitting with his arms wrapped around his legs and his head bowed between his knees.

Translate: I said, "My sweet master, observe how that soul seems to be more neglected as if laziness were his companion."

Original: Allor si volse a noi e puose mente, movendo ’l viso pur su per la coscia, e disse
Translate: He then looked at us with the look that flowed along his legs and uttered

Original: Conobbi allor chi era, e quella angoscia che m’avacciava un poco ancor la lena, non m’impedì l’andare a lui
Translate: I immediately recognized that person and, despite my breath, I took courage and went to him.

Original: e poscia ch’a lui fu’ giunto, alzò la testa a pena, dicendo
Translate: After reaching him, he just lifted up his head and said to me

Original: Li atti suoi pigri e le corte parole mosser le labbra mie un poco a riso
Translate: His lazy behavior and monosillabes made me smile a little.

Original: poi cominciai

Original: «Belacqua, a me non dole di te omai
Translate: "Belacqua, I'm no longer in pain for you.

Original: ma dimmi

Original: perché assiso quiritto se’? attendi tu iscorta, o pur lo modo usato t’ha’ ripriso?»
Translate: Are you sitting here for a specific reason? Are you waiting for a guide or are the notes of ancient rituals resonating?

Original: Ed elli
Translate: And him

Original: «O frate, andar in sù che porta? ché non mi lascerebbe ire a’ martìri l’angel di Dio che siede in su la porta
Translate: Oh brother, what can compel me to try to reach the pains of the heavenly abode when the Guardian Angel watches the door?

Original: Prima convien che tanto il ciel m’aggiri di fuor da essa, quanto fece in vita, per ch’io ’ndugiai al fine i buon sospiri,
Translate: Having lingered in my hesitation to rehabilitate me to the last, it is necessary that the sky around me at the Antipurgatory swirl with the same frequency as previously seen.

Original: se orazïone in prima non m’aita che surga sù di cuor che in grazia viva
Translate: May a sincere prayer, offered with the sentiments of a heart in grace with God, come to help me.

Original: l’altra che val, che ’n ciel non è udita?»
Translate: In heaven, despite the invocation of another prayer also, it would be unheard.

Original: E già il poeta innanzi mi saliva, e dicea
Translate: As Virgil moved to go up in front of me and said,

Original: «Vienne omai
Translate: He's come by now.

Original: vedi ch’è tocco meridïan dal sole e a la riva cuopre la notte già col piè Morrocco»
Translate: The sun comes to its noon, while the darkness falls on the Moroccan coast.

Original: Io era già da quell’ ombre partito, e seguitava l’orme del mio duca, quando di retro a me, drizzando ’l dito, una gridò
Translate: I had already left these souls to follow my lead, when one of them, pointing his finger at me, screamed behind me.

Original: «Ve’ che non par che luca lo raggio da sinistra a quel di sotto, e come vivo par che si conduca»
Translate: The ray of the sun from the left does not create sufficient illumination to counteract the amount of light emitted by the next, which projects a clear shadow.

Original: Li occhi rivolsi al suon di questo motto, e vidile guardar per maraviglia pur me, pur me, e ’l lume ch’era rotto
Translate: Surprises arose when I crossed my eyes with those souls as the sunlight was blocked by my figure.

Original: «Perché l’animo tuo tanto s’impiglia», disse ’l maestro, «che l’andare allenti?
Translate: The teacher asked me why my attention was distracted to the point of compromising my progress?

Original: che ti fa ciò che quivi si pispiglia? Vien dietro a me, e lascia dir le genti
Translate: Ignore what people say, focus on me and proceed!

Original: sta come torre ferma, che non crolla già mai la cima per soffiar di venti
Translate: Stand straight as a rock, it won't waver even when the winds blow louder.

Original: ché sempre l’omo in cui pensier rampolla sovra pensier, da sé dilunga il segno, perché la foga l’un de l’altro insolla»
Translate: For an individual, when a consideration generates the need to make others later, it becomes difficult to reach the target set instead of being increased by the sum of the previous ones.

Original: Che potea io ridir, se non «Io vegno»? Dissilo, alquanto del color consperso che fa l’uom di perdon talvolta degno
Translate: What else could I say but "I'll accompany you"? I said it, blushing as often does a man who deserves to be forgiven.

Original: E ’ntanto per la costa di traverso venivan genti innanzi a noi un poco, cantando ‘Miserere’ a verso a verso
Translate: As we descended on a rocky ridge that crossed the mountain, not far away presences came to us into the Psalm 'Miserere' in pairs.

Original: Quando s’accorser ch’i’ non dava loco per lo mio corpo al trapassar d’i raggi, mutar lor canto in un «oh»
Translate: As soon as they realized that the rays of the sun were prevented from passing through my body, they turned their song into a slight "Oh."

Original: lungo e roco
Translate: Thin and weak

Original: e due di loro, in forma di messaggi, corsero incontr’ a noi e dimandarne
Translate: Two people, as ambassadors, rushed to us and begged us.

Original: «Di vostra condizion fatene saggi»
Translate: Please let us know how you are.

Original: E ’l mio maestro
Translate: My teacher

Original: «Voi potete andarne e ritrarre a color che vi mandaro che ’l corpo di costui è vera carne
Translate: You can tell those who sent you here that his body is alive and well.

Original: Se per veder la sua ombra restaro, com’ io avviso, assai è lor risposto
Translate: I think they got stuck seeing his profile, so I said enough.

Original: fàccianli onore, ed esser può lor caro»
Translate: It will be beneficial for them if they accept them with kindness.

Original: Vapori accesi non vid’ io sì tosto di prima notte mai fender sereno, né, sol calando, nuvole d’agosto, che color non tornasser suso in meno
Translate: Never have I seen an event as fast as the return of those souls above, equal to falling stars that tear the sky at the first drop of darkness or flashes that cut the clouds of summer, at the sunset.

Original: e, giunti là, con li altri a noi dier volta, come schiera che scorre sanza freno
Translate: They joined us with the others, running wildly like a marching army.

Original: «Questa gente che preme a noi è molta, e vegnonti a pregar», disse ’l poeta
Translate: "Virgilio commented that there was a great crowd of people gathered around them, and that they came to beg for your blessing.

Original: «però pur va, e in andando ascolta»
Translate: As you move, keep your direction and listen.

Original: «O anima che vai per esser lieta con quelle membra con le quai nascesti», venian gridando, «un poco il passo queta
Translate: They shouted "Stop for a moment, or be that you seek happiness! Use the body with which you were born and don't speed up too much!

Original: Guarda s’alcun di noi unqua vedesti, sì che di lui di là novella porti
Translate: See if you can find one of us wherever you go, so you can tell us something about our journey to Earth.

Original: deh, perché vai? deh, perché non t’arresti? Noi fummo tutti già per forza morti, e peccatori infino a l’ultima ora
Translate: Come on, why don't we put an end to our walking after living such a tragic experience and being considered sinners until the last moment?

Original: quivi lume del ciel ne fece accorti, sì che, pentendo e perdonando, fora di vita uscimmo a Dio pacificati,

Translate: Prayers came out of my mouth as my fellow countrymen engaged in confrontation with their opponents at Colle Val d'Elsa, begging for divine blessing on what would happen.

Original: “Omai più non ti temo”,
Translate: I'm not afraid of you anymore.

Original: come fé ’l merlo per poca bonaccia

Original: e ancor non sarebbe lo mio dover per penitenza scemo,

Translate: I reported that my eyes had been forced to remain within this frame because, even if only slightly, I had directed them with envy

Original: Troppa è più la paura ond’ è sospesa l’anima mia del tormento di sotto, che già lo ’ncarco di là giù mi pesa»
Translate: My shoulders already feel the weight of the terrible threat of the Frame below, making me feel a deeper fear than the mass of the rock that is down there.

Original: Ed ella a me

Original: E io

Original: «Costui ch’è meco e non fa motto
Translate: Even though he's by my side,

Translate: He replied "What a marvel!" This is an evident sign of God's love for you.

Translate: so, from time to time, think of me during your prayers

Translate: You will meet them among that vain group of people, who hope for wealth in Talamone and end up spending more money than they spent trying to discover the Diana Tower.

Original: ma più vi perderanno li ammiragli»
Translate: Contractors will be more affected by the negative consequences.

Original: «Chi è costui che ’l nostro monte cerchia prima che morte li abbia dato il volo, e apre li occhi a sua voglia e coverchia?»
Translate: Who is this that walks on our mountain, breathing again and controlling its own luminosity of eyes at will?

Original: «Non so chi sia, ma so ch’e’ non è solo

Original: domandal tu che più li t’avvicini, e dolcemente, sì che parli, acco’lo»
Translate: You ask the question now that you're closer to him, and treat him kindly to encourage him to talk to us.

Translate: Two souls, their heads close to each other, were talking about me on my right.

Original: e disse l’uno

Translate: "O soul that you go to heaven when you are still in the body, in the name of charity console us and tell us where you come from and who you are."

Original: ché tu ne fai tanto maravigliar de la tua grazia, quanto vuol cosa che non fu più mai»
Translate: With the grace you receive, you are able to amaze us with something we have never seen before.

Original: E io
Translate: I didn't know what to do. I had no idea how to move.

Translate: A small stream that begins on the Falterona, and extends for more than 100 miles through the central region of Tuscany.

Translate: If I wanted to say my name, it would be useless because it is not yet well known.

Original: E l’altro disse lui
Translate: The other asked

Original: E l’ombra che di ciò domandata era, si sdebitò così

Original: «Non so

Translate: All flee from virtues as if these were snakes, either because of their situation or because they absorbed bad behaviors that lead them to do so.

Translate: So changed is the nature of the inhabitants of the poor valley, as if they had been transformed into beasts by Circe.

Original: Tra brutti porci, più degni di galle che d’altro cibo fatto in uman uso, dirizza prima il suo povero calle
Translate: Its modest route initially crosses the Val d'Arno, a place that is more suited to the search for acorns by pigs, rather than to the consumption of other foods by humans.

Original: Né lascerò di dir perch’ altri m’oda

Original: e buon sarà costui, s’ancor s’ammenta di ciò che vero spirto mi disnoda

Original: Vende la carne loro essendo viva

Original: poscia li ancide come antica belva

Original: molti di vita e sé di pregio priva

Original: Sanguinoso esce de la trista selva

Original: lasciala tal, che di qui a mille anni ne lo stato primaio non si rinselva»

Original: per che lo spirto che di pria parlòmi ricominciò

Original: «Tu vuo’ ch’io mi deduca nel fare a te ciò che tu far non vuo’mi
Translate: You want me to lead you to do what you deny me.

Original: però sappi ch’io fui Guido del Duca
Translate: Guido, the former Duke, you know.

Translate: My envy was so intense that if I saw someone enjoying a moment of happiness, I would become bruised.

Original: Di mia semente cotal paglia mieto
Translate: Retrieving this straw from that seed

Original: o gente umana, perché poni ’l core là ’v’ è mestier di consorte divieto?
Translate: Why do you want things that sharing doesn't allow you to possess, that is, human beings?

Original: Questi è Rinier
Translate: There's Rinieri.

Translate: The illustrious House of the Calboli has gained honor and fame over the years, however no one has managed to maintain and perpetuate their tradition of greatness.

Original: E non pur lo suo sangue è fatto brullo, tra ’l Po e ’l monte e la marina e ’l Reno, del ben richesto al vero e al trastullo
Translate: Between the Po, the peaks, the Adriatic and the Rhine came a time when his descendants gave up the virtues necessary for the real and the courteous pastimes.

Original: ché dentro a questi termini è ripieno di venenosi sterpi, sì che tardi per coltivare omai verrebber meno
Translate: Within these areas, the main obstacle to the cultivation of the earth is the great presence of doc, thorny shrubs that develop a lethal poison. It would be difficult to remove all specimens so as to allow the earth to return to produce.

Translate: Where is the kindness of Lizio and Arrigo Mainardi? And Pier Traversaro and Guido di Carpegna? Oh, Romagnoli lost in molasses!

Translate: Don't be surprised, Tuscany, if they shed tears when I remember Guido da Prata, Ugolino d'Azzo who joined us, Federigo Tignoso and his company.

Translate: People seemed to be urged by love and kindness to pursue military efforts and worldly elegance, but nowadays hearts have become evil.

Original: e mal fa Castrocaro, e peggio Conio, che di figliar tai conti più s’impiglia

Translate: When their demon is gone, the Pagans will be fine.

Original: ma non però che puro già mai rimagna d’essi testimonio
Translate: but to the point that the memory of him is preserved

Translate: O Ugolino dei Fantolini, your name will also be remembered in the future because there is no risk that it will be forgotten thanks to your absence of unbecoming descendants.

Original: Ma va via, Tosco, omai

Original: ch’or mi diletta troppo di pianger più che di parlare, sì m’ha nostra ragion la mente stretta»
Translate: I have so much sadness inside that it makes me unable to speak, our speech was so painful.

Original: e allor, per ristrignermi al poeta, in destro feci, e non innanzi, il passo

Translate: That was the strict limit that should contain man within his borders.

Original: onde vi batte chi tutto discerne»

Translate: Similar to a child playing, the sun runs through the space from dawn to the third hour of the day.

Original: tanto pareva già inver’ la sera essere al sol del suo corso rimaso

Original: vespero là, e qui mezza notte era

Translate: In our tour around the mountain, with faces facing the west, we were hit in full by dazzling rays of sunshine.

Original: ond’ io levai le mani inver’ la cima de le mie ciglia, e fecimi ’l solecchio, che del soverchio visibile lima
Translate: Then I raised my hands to cover my eyes with excessive light compared to what I could bear.

Original: Come quando da l’acqua o da lo specchio salta lo raggio a l’opposita parte, salendo su per lo modo parecchio a quel che scende,
Translate: Similarly to the ray of light that is reflected by water or a mirror, forming an angle equal to that of the radius that falls in relation to the vertical with respect to the plane.

Original: e tanto si diparte dal cader de la pietra in igual tratta, sì come mostra esperïenza e arte
Translate: According to science and experience.

Translate: I had the feeling that a reflected light hit me at that point.

Original: per che a fuggir la mia vista fu ratta

Translate: That's an angel who summons us to fly

Original: Poi giunti fummo a l’angel benedetto, con lieta voce disse

Original: «Intrate quinci ad un scaleo vie men che li altri eretto»
Translate: You can climb this ladder more gently than the others.

Translate: We were moving away from that area, singing 'Blessed are the merciful' and 'Enjoy who wins'.

Original: Per ch’elli a me

Translate: He is aware of the gravity of his greatest error

Translate: The more people enjoy good in Heaven, the greater is the overall well-being they possess and they light up of mutual love.

Original: «Io son d’esser contento più digiuno», diss’ io, «che se mi fosse pria taciuto, e più di dubbio ne la mente aduno
Translate: I said that, compared to when I didn't ask any questions, they are farther away from feeling satisfied and I still keep several questions in my head.

Translate: How can a good, shared among several people, make the latter richer than those who possessed it alone?

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: He told me

Original: «Però che tu rificchi la mente pur a le cose terrene, di vera luce tenebre dispicchi
Translate: "Because you focus exclusively on material goods, consider the true light as a darkness.

Original: Tanto si dà quanto trova d’ardore

Translate: If you are not satisfied with my reasoning, then Beatrice will be there to satisfy all your desires and to satisfy them completely.

Original: Procaccia pur che tosto sieno spente, come son già le due, le cinque piaghe, che si richiudon per esser dolente»
Translate: Hurry up and remove the other five Ps, just like you did with the first two who were eliminated for your repentance.

Original: Ivi mi parve in una visïone estatica di sùbito esser tratto, e vedere in un tempio più persone

Original: e una donna, in su l’entrar, con atto dolce di madre dicer
Translate: There was a woman on the door, with the sweet expression of a mother talking.

Translate: Son, what made you talk to us like that? Your father and I were very sad not to see you.

Original: E come qui si tacque, ciò che pareva prima, dispario
Translate: Instantly, the scene dissolved from the mind when silence ceased.

Original: Indi m’apparve un’altra con quell’ acque giù per le gote che ’l dolor distilla quando di gran dispetto in altrui nacque, e dir
Translate: Later, another woman appeared before me with her cheeks striped with tears born out of a great sense of anger toward someone, speaking words

Original: «Se tu se’ sire de la villa del cui nome ne’ dèi fu tanta lite, e onde ogne scïenza disfavilla,
Translate: In thy dominion is the city for which a divine controversy arose, and from which all the teachings of knowledge have emerged.

Original: vendica te di quelle braccia ardite ch’abbracciar nostra figlia, o Pisistràto»
Translate: Avenge those reckless arms that have held our daughter, O Pisistrate!

Original: E ’l segnor mi parea, benigno e mite, risponder lei con viso temperato
Translate: It seemed that the benevolent and mild ladies replied with a serene expression.

Original: «Che farem noi a chi mal ne disira, se quei che ci ama è per noi condannato?»,
Translate: What should we do to those who want to hurt us if we punish those who love us?

Original: Poi vidi genti accese in foco d’ira con pietre un giovinetto ancider, forte gridando a sé pur
Translate: When I turned around I saw a group of people stoned a young man, screaming angry at each other in anger.

Original: «Martira, martira»

Translate: In observing the traces that the angel has impressed on Dante's forehead, it is understood how worthy he is to be a chosen one among the blessed.

Original: ma per vento che ’n terra si nasconda, non so come, qua sù non tremò mai

Translate: For over five hundred years I endured this condemnation, until recently when I was finally allowed to move to other places

Original: de l’Eneïda dico, la qual mamma fummi, e fummi nutrice, poetando

Original: sanz’ essa non fermai peso di dramma

Translate: Stazio's shadow remained silent and stared into my eyes, a place where feelings can be read more easily.

Original: e «Se tanto labore in bene assommi», disse,

Original: «perché la tua faccia testeso un lampeggiar di riso dimostrommi?»

Translate: Please approach the river so I can hear what song you're singing.

Translate: Remind me of the story of Proserpina and her mother when she was lost in the eternal spring.

Original: Come si volge, con le piante strette a terra e intra sé, donna che balli, e piede innanzi piede a pena mette,

Original: più odio da Leandro non sofferse per mareggiare intra Sesto e Abido, che quel da me perch’ allor non s’aperse
Translate: Leandro no longer felt any aversion to the river that had prevented my passage from Sesto to Abido, because of its intense tides.

Original: «Voi siete nuovi, e forse perch’ io rido»,
Translate: You just made your way in, so I feel like laughing at it.

Original: cominciò ella,
Translate: she began,

Original: «in questo luogo eletto a l’umana natura per suo nido, maravigliando tienvi alcun sospetto
Translate: This place, chosen as a home for mankind, gives you wonder

Translate: The Psalm 'Deletasts' provides an answer that can dissipate all your uncertainty.

Original: E tu che se’ dinanzi e mi pregasti, dì s’altro vuoli udir
Translate: You, standing in front of me and asking me the question, let me know if you want to know anything else.

Original: ch’i’ venni presta ad ogne tua question tanto che basti»
Translate: In fact, I am here to give an exhaustive answer to each of your questions.

Original: «L’acqua», diss’ io, «e ’l suon de la foresta impugnan dentro a me novella fede di cosa ch’io udi’ contraria a questa»
Translate: I reported that the water and rustling of the forest leaves opposed something I had been exposed to.

Original: Ond’ ella
Translate: Then you

Original: «Io dicerò come procede per sua cagion ciò ch’ammirar ti face, e purgherò la nebbia che ti fiede
Translate: I will explain to you the origin of your wonder and dissipate the doubts that obscure your mind.

Original: Lo sommo Ben, che solo esso a sé piace, fé l’uom buono e a bene, e questo loco diede per arr’ a lui d’etterna pace
Translate: God, who loves only himself, created the good man and prone to goodness, and gave him this world as a symbol of perpetual peace.

Original: Per sua difalta qui dimorò poco
Translate: Because of his mistake, he only stayed in this place for a short time.

Original: per sua difalta in pianto e in affanno cambiò onesto riso e dolce gioco
Translate: Because of his sin, his joy and joy turned into tears and torment.

Original: Perché ’l turbar che sotto da sé fanno l’essalazion de l’acqua e de la terra,
Translate: The perturbations caused on Earth by water vapor and soil must be addressed.

Original: che quanto posson dietro al calor vanno, a l’uomo non facesse alcuna guerra, questo monte salìo verso ’l ciel tanto,
Translate: Following the heat as far as they could without disturbing man, this mountain has risen to the sky up here.

Original: e libero n’è d’indi ove si serra
Translate: From here to Purgatory, it is protected from atmospheric phenomena.

Translate: Since the Primo Mobile makes the air move in a continuous circulation, unless it's interrupted somewhere,

Translate: The plant, hit by the wind, has such an impact that it spreads its generative virtue through the air that revolves around and carries on a beneficial effect.

Original: e l’altra terra, secondo ch’è degna per sé e per suo ciel, concepe e figlia di diverse virtù diverse legna
Translate: Depending on its fertility and climate, the Earth conceives and generates various plants with different characteristics thanks to the ability of men.

Translate: You must be aware that the sacred place where you find yourself keeps all kinds of seed and is rich in fruits that are not common elsewhere.

Original: L’acqua che vedi non surge di vena che ristori vapor che gel converta, come fiume ch’acquista e perde lena
Translate: The water you observe is not of meteotic origin, nor is it produced by frost transforming atmospheric vapours into rain as it could happen with a stream that rises and falls in flow.

Translate: On this side you descend with the power to remove the allurement of sin.

Translate: this taste is unparalleled

Original: né credo che ’l mio dir ti sia men caro, se oltre promession teco si spazia

Original: Quelli ch’anticamente poetaro l’età de l’oro e suo stato felice, forse in Parnaso esto loco sognaro
Translate: Those who in ancient times dreamed of a paradiselike place in Parnasus, wrote verses about the renowned and happy golden age.

Original: Qui fu innocente l’umana radice

Original: qui primavera sempre e ogne frutto
Translate: Here reigns an eternal spring and every fruit

Original: nettare è questo di che ciascun dice»
Translate: "Everyone talks about the precious properties of this river's water."

Translate: When I turned to Virgil and Statius, I noticed that they had smiled when they heard these last words.

Original: poi a la bella donna torna’ il viso

Translate: Because the lightning was gone quickly, but that light was getting brighter and brighter, I thought between me and myself.

Original: ‘Che cosa è questa?’
Translate: What could it be?

Original: E una melodia dolce correva per l’aere luminoso
Translate: The sweetness of the melody poured into the luminous atmosphere.

Original: onde buon zelo mi fé riprender l’ardimento d’Eva, che là dove ubidia la terra e ’l cielo,
Translate: Then a righteous ardour spurred me to rebuke Eve's excessive arrogance, even though the earth and heaven obeyed her.

Original: femmina, sola e pur testé formata, non sofferse di star sotto alcun velo
Translate: Although she was the first woman created, I didn't let there be any limitations in my education.

Original: sotto ’l qual se divota fosse stata, avrei quelle ineffabili delizie sentite prima e più lunga fïata

Original: Mentr’ io m’andava tra tante primizie de l’etterno piacer tutto sospeso,
Translate: Proceeding with my heart full of hope for all the wonders that awaited me, I went on.

Original: e disïoso ancora a più letizie, dinanzi a noi, tal quale un foco acceso, ci si fé l’aere sotto i verdi rami
Translate: And desirous of other joys, the air was made before us a red color as the fire, under the green branches.

Original: e ’l dolce suon per canti era già inteso
Translate: and that sweet sound was becoming, to all intents and purposes, a melody

Translate: O holy Muse, if ever I have suffered food deprivation, cold or be awake at night because of you, now inevitable desire becomes stronger in me to receive a recognition for all this.

Translate: Speaking to the Helicopter to grant me the poetic inspiration, and with the help of Urania and other Muse he also verses things that may seem impossible to realize.

Original: ma quand’ i’ fui sì presso di lor fatto, che l’obietto comun, che ’l senso inganna,
Translate: When I got close enough to make a decision, the thing I had initially sensed, that could confuse the senses,

Original: e ne le voci del cantare ‘Osanna’

Original: e tal candor di qua già mai non fuci

Translate: From far away it was no longer possible to see how high their peaks were

Original: l’una tanto rossa ch’a pena fora dentro al foco nota

Translate: Four women dressed in a deep purple red moved gracefully to the left of the chariot, following the enchanted rhythm that came from the head of their dancer from the three pupils.

Translate: of roses and red flowers, but not only

Translate: Bless you for coming.

Translate: As soon as I saw the high loving virtue that had already touched my heart before I left my childhood, my sight was struck.

Translate: I turned to the left with the anxiety with which the child runs to Mother, when he is afraid or upset by something, to tell Virgilio

Translate: There's not a single drop of my blood safe from tremor.

Translate: Virgil, dear father, had abandoned us all, but I had entrusted myself to him to save me.

Translate: Dante, do not despair for the departure of Virgil; hold your tears and avoid crying.

Original: «Guardaci ben

Translate: Watch in God's eternal light in such a way that you do not miss any movement of the world in its progress, both during the night and the day.

Original: Alcun tempo il sostenni col mio volto

Translate: When I entered my teenage phase and changed my life, he betrayed my memory and began to associate with other women.

Translate: Crying, I approached the threshold of Hell and turned my prayer to those who were responsible for his arrival at this place.

Original: Alto fato di Dio sarebbe rotto, se Letè si passasse e tal vivanda fosse gustata sanza alcuno scotto di pentimento che lagrime spanda»
Translate: Dante would not be part of the Lord's plan if he could overcome the Lete and eat something without feeling a remorse so deep as to cry.

Original: «O tu che se’ di là dal fiume sacro»,

Original: «dì, dì se questo è vero

Original: Poco sofferse

Original: poi disse
Translate: afterward he said,

Translate: What do you think? Answer me,

Translate: From the water of Lete, the memory of sin has not yet been defeated in you.

Original: Come balestro frange, quando scocca da troppa tesa, la sua corda e l’arco,
Translate: Like a rope and the bow break when you pull the arrow with too much force, like a crossbow.

Translate: With limited force, the dart reached its destination and I collapsed under the oppression of despair, weeping and panting. My voice was weak and faint.

Original: Ond’ ella a me
Translate: At that point, you told me

Translate: By fulfilling my impulse that led you to nourish love for the supreme good, beyond which you cannot aspire to anything more.

Original: quai fossi attraversati o quai catene trovasti, per che del passare innanzi dovessiti così spogliar la spene?
Translate: What barriers - ditches or chains - have you encountered, that have caused me to abandon you to the idea of not being able to go any further?

Original: E quali agevolezze o quali avanzi ne la fronte de li altri si mostraro, per che dovessi lor passeggiare anzi?»
Translate: What relief, what benefits did you have with the other goods for which you wished to purchase them?

Original: Dopo la tratta d’un sospiro amaro, a pena ebbi la voce che rispuose, e le labbra a fatica la formaro
Translate: Dopso having breathed a painfully bitter sigh, I almost couldn't find my voice to answer and be able to utter words was very difficult.

Original: Piangendo dissi

Original: Ed ella

Translate: Even if you refused or denied what you admitted, your infringement would remain equally clear.

Translate: There is no aspect of nature or art that can compete with the beauty of the mortal body in which I was imprisoned, now reduced to dust underground.

Original: e se ’l sommo piacer sì ti fallio per la mia morte, qual cosa mortale dovea poi trarre te nel suo disio?

Translate: He should not have let you fly down, waiting for more strokes of fate, a young woman or another vain and ephemeral earthly good

Translate: In the face of adult birds, the hunter's efforts to lay the nets or strike arrows are unsuccessful.

Translate: I was there with an embarrassed air, quietly, looking down and accepting my responsibility, feeling regret for what I had done.

Original: ed ella disse
Translate: she exclaimed

Translate: A powerful wind, whether it came from our land or the one blown from Africa, has uprooted a robust hill with greater ease than I have raised my chin to his will.

Translate: When he told me the word "shave," I immediately understood his severe rebuke and looked up immediately.

Translate: with eyes that were still uncertain, I saw Beatrice face to the party that was just a two-faced being.

Translate: Even though she was veiled and beyond the river, she seemed to surpass herself in beauty when she was alive, more than she, when she was alive, surpassed all the other women.

Translate: The thorn of atonement pricked me so much, that all other things were overwhelmed by the one that most removed my love for Beatrice and became unbearable.

Original: e quale allora femmi, salsi colei che la cagion mi porse

Translate: We on Earth are nymphs, while in heaven we are shining stars

Original: Tant’ eran li occhi miei fissi e attenti a disbramarsi la decenne sete, che li altri sensi m’eran tutti spenti

Original: Ed essi quinci e quindi avien parete di non caler

Original: — così lo santo riso a sé traéli con l’antica rete —

Translate: As we entered the thick and desolate forest, because of her naivety that trusted the serpent, our steps were accompanied by a melodious angelic song.

Original: Forse in tre voli tanto spazio prese disfrenata saetta, quanto eramo rimossi, quando Bëatrice scese
Translate: When Beatrice got out of the wagon, we might have walked the distance that would cover an arrow hurled three times.

Original: Io senti’ mormorare a tutti «Adamo»

Translate: His thick hair, which gradually branched upward, would be admired by the Indians in their woods for its grandeur.

Translate: The others around the solid tree exclaimed so

Original: e l’animal binato
Translate: the dual-character animal

Original: «Sì si conserva il seme d’ogne giusto»

Translate: When the great glow of the sun joins the light that shines in the constellation Pisces, it is as if our plants were illuminated.

Original: turgide fansi,
Translate: they harden

Translate: I didn't understand, here on Earth you can't hear the song that those people were singing at that time and I couldn't hear all the tones.

Original: S’io potessi ritrar come assonnaro li occhi spietati udendo di Siringa, li occhi a cui pur vegghiar costò sì caro
Translate: If I had the ability to narrate how ruthless eyes succumbed to sleep by listening to the epic relationship of Syringe, those very eyes that paid dearly by remaining vigilant.

Original: come pintor che con essempro pinga, disegnerei com’ io m’addormentai

Original: ma qual vuol sia che l’assonnar ben finga
